pubList.title: Detecting Frames in News Headlines and Its Application to Analyzing News Framing Trends Surrounding U.S. Gun Violence
pubList.text: Siyi Liu, Lei Guo, Kate Mays, Margrit Betke, Derry Wijaya. Proc. of CoNLL 2019

caseStudiesDetailsDesc.paragraph1: In this work, we research methods for framing analysis and identification. Different news articles about the same topic often offer a variety of perspectives: an article written about gun violence might emphasize gun control, while another might promote 2nd Amendment rights, and yet a third might focus on mental health issues. In communication research, these different perspectives are known as “frames”, which, when used in news media will influence the opinion of their readers in multiple ways. In this project, in collaboration with communication researchers, we curate and provide expert annotations of news articles with their frames, and research and develop models for effectively detecting frames in news articles.
caseStudiesDetailsDesc.paragraph2: We have constructed datasets of news articles annotated with their frames, covering several important public affairs issues including U.S. gun violence (released), COVID-19 (released), climate change (ongoing), and immigration (ongoing). We have also developed models for effective frame detection in multiple languages, even those with few training data (released), and using multiple modalities including texts,  images, and videos and in multiple platforms including news and social media texts (ongoing).
caseStudiesDetailsDesc.paragraph4: We are currently building a Web-based system (OpenFraming) for analyzing and classifying frames in text documents in multiple languages. Our goal is to make effective tools for automatic frame discovery and labeling based on topic modeling and our proposed models widely accessible to researchers from a diverse array of disciplines. To this end, we provide both state-of-the-art pre-trained frame classification models on various issues as well as a user-friendly pipeline for training novel classification models on user-provided corpora. Researchers can submit their documents and obtain frames of the documents. The degree of user involvement is flexible: they can run models that have been pre-trained on select issues; submit labeled documents and train a new model for frame classification; or submit unlabeled documents and obtain potential frames of the documents. The code making up our system is also open-sourced and well-documented, making the system transparent and expandable.

pubList.title: Detecting reports of unsafe foods in consumer product reviews
pubList.text: Adyasha Maharana, Kunlin Cai, Joseph Hellerstein, Yulin Hswen, Michael Munsell, Valentina Staneva, Miki Verma, Cynthia Vint, Derry Wijaya, Elaine O Nsoesie. JAMIA Open, 2019

caseStudiesDetailsDesc.paragraph1: In this work, we research applications of NLP models to  analyze important public health issues in user-generated contents such as customer reviews and social media discussions. With colleagues from Boston University Medical Campus and Public Health, and Communications, we have applied NLP models to detect unsafe foods in customer product reviews, analyze discussions of miscarriage and preterm births on Twitter, and infer demography of users and analyze discussions of e-cigarette on Twitter.
caseStudiesDetailsDesc.paragraph4: In the recent decade, e-cigarette use among youth in the U.S. has significantly increased. In addition to its negative health implications, e-cigarette use also increases the likelihood to transition to combustible cigarette smoking and addiction to other drugs. While there are many e-cigarette policies, to date, little is known about the varying levels of e-cigarette and tobacco policies across states to reduce e-cigarette consumption. Since social media is pervasive, there is a growing trend of leveraging social media as part of public health initiatives. Social media postings can also reveal public sentiment toward health policies. We are developing models to assess the effects of tobacco control policies and public sentiment on e-cigarette use by analyzing e-cigarette discussions in social media such as Twitter in connection to various health policies, and retail data. The findings of this study will contribute to our understanding of the mechanism involving tobacco policies, public sentiment on vaping, and youth e-cigarette consumption. We hope that the results of this study will help policy implementation at the federal level and social-media campaigns to prevent and reduce youth e-cigarette use.

caseStudiesDetailsDesc.paragraph1: In this work we investigate the role of language in few-shot incremental learning. Specifically we study the image classification task where there are a set of base classes with abundant examples and a set of novel classes from which only few samples are available. The goal in few-shot incremental learning is to acquire new concepts without forgetting what's previously learned. We inspire from the use of language in zero-shot learning and inquire the effect of language in shaping the learning in image space.

pubList.title: Learning Translations via Matrix Completion
pubList.text: Derry Wijaya, Brendan Callahan, John Hewitt, Jie Gao, Xiao Ling, Marianna Apidianaki, Chris Callison-Burch. Proc. of EMNLP 2017

caseStudiesDetailsDesc.paragraph1: In this work, we research methods for training effective machine translation models when there are few/no parallel data (i.e., human translation data) to train the models, which is the case for the majority of languages in the world, including the informal use of languages in social contexts. We investigate unsupervised and semi-supervised methods for translation that leverage monolingual and comparable texts, readily-available bilingual resources such as dictionaries, and other potential signals for translation such as images.
caseStudiesDetailsDesc.paragraph2: With collaborators at UPenn, we constructed and publicly released the Massively Multilingual Image Dataset (MMID), which is a large-scale, massively multilingual dataset of images paired with the words they represent. The dataset is doubly parallel: for each language, words are stored parallel to images that represent the word, and parallel to the word’s translation into English (and corresponding images.) MMID is by far the largest dataset of its kind, it has 98 languages (including English) and up to 10k words per language (and many more for English.), and up to 100 images per word. We also released models for lexical translation that leverage small dictionaries (up to 10k words), Wikipedia interlingual links, and images, and without parallel data.

pubList.title: Informativity in Image Captions vs. Referring Expressions.
pubList.text: E. Coppock, D. Dionne, N. Graham, E. Ganem, S. Zhao, S. Lin, W. Liu and D. Wijaya. Proc. of Probability and Meaning, 2020 (PaM2020).

caseStudiesDetailsInfo.title: Grant
caseStudiesDetailsInfo.subTitle: Hariri - Bridging Linguistic and Visual Knowledge (REG)

caseStudiesDetailsDesc.paragraph1: At the intersection between computer vision and natural language processing, there has been recent progress on two natural language generation tasks: Image Captioning and Referring Expression Generation for objects in complex scenes. The former aims to provide a caption for a specified object in a complex scene for the benefit of an interlocutor who may not be able to see it. The latter aims to produce a referring expression that will serve to identify a given object in a scene that the interlocutor can see. The two tasks are designed for different assumptions about the common ground between the interlocutors, and serve very different purposes, although they both associate a linguistic description with an object in a complex scene. Despite these fundamental differences, the distinction between these two tasks is sometimes overlooked.
caseStudiesDetailsDesc.paragraph2: In this project, in collaborations with colleagues from the Linguistics Department, we undertake a side-by-side comparison between image captioning and reference game human datasets and show that they differ systematically with respect to informativity. We also develop a model for referring expression generation that models the task as a two-agent cooperative scheme following Gricean maxims in which a 'speaker' agent would generate the expression that best describes a targeted area and a 'listener' agent would identify the target.  Specifically, we explore the Rational Speech Act framework (RSA), a broadly Gricean yet probabilistic approach to pragmatics, which has been shown to generate high quality and explainable expressions on toy datasets, but whose application to large scale problems remains largely unexplored. Our proposed model applies a combination of the RSA framework and deep learning approaches to larger datasets with the aim of generating better-explained expressions while not sacrificing the performance of the system.
caseStudiesDetailsDesc.paragraph4: In this project, in collaborations with colleagues from Communications, the Pardee School of Global Studies, and the International Monetary Fund (IMF), we curate datasets and explore NLP models for analyzing sentiment of financial news in multiple languages on Chinese economy, which will be used in relation with other financial data to construct a reliable index of the country's economy.
